skills.name: Alphabet 2:
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Initial Consonants**

As mentioned in the previous skill, Korean syllable blocks are formed from a consonant and a vowel.  In this lesson we'll introduce **initial consonants**.

####**Basic Consonants**

|  | Romanization | Pronunciation  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | m | /m/ |
|  | n | /n/ |
|  | ng | // (no sound at start of syllable)  |
|  | g | /g/ or /k/  |
|  | b | /b/ or /p/  |
|  | d | /d/ or /t/ |
|  | l/r | //or /l/ |
|  | j | // **j**am |
|  | s | /s/ or // |

, , and  can represent either voiced or unvoiced sounds (g/k, b/p, and d/t), depending on the surrounding sounds.  The most important aspect is that there should be no air coming from your mouth while saying these sounds.

 is like a Spanish r at the beginning of a syllable, where the tip of the tongue hits the top of your mouth very briefly. 

 in most situations sounds like an s, but before  or so-called iotized vowels (, , , )  it sounds more like "sh".

####**Aspirants**

|  | Romanization | Pronunciation  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | k | /k/ |
|  | p | /p/ |
|  | t | /t/ |
|  | ch | /t/ |
|  | h | /h/ |

**Aspirants** are consonants followed by a puff of air.  Hold a small sheet of paper in front of your mouth.  Notice that the paper moves when you pronounce the English words pen and touch due to the aspiration.

####**Tense Consonants**

|  | Romanization | Pronunciation  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | kk | /k/ |
|  | pp | /p/ |
|  | tt | /t/ |
|  | jj | /t/ |
|  | ss | /s/ |

**Tense consonants** are pronounced with extra emphasis. Listen carefully to the pronunciation in the course.  It's difficult for most English speakers to master, but it'll come in time. 

Sometimes regular , , , , and  become tense in the middle of words, especially for younger speakers.

skills.name: Borrowings
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Loan Words**

Before we wade into Korean grammar and vocabulary, let's get some more alphabet practice with some words you should already know.

###**Anglicization vs Korean**

We introduce two of the most famous Korean companies, Samsung and Hyundai. Don't be surprised that some companies and given names don't fit the romanization we're using.

Korean has had several standard systems of romanization over the years, with Revised Romanization currently the official system in use by South Korea and in this course. It came about in the 90s, so proper nouns and words that had previously entered English often make use of one of the older systems.

This gives us Samsung and Hyundai rather than "samseong" and "hyeondae".

###**Transliteration**

Transliteration into Korean is based on Korean approximation of English pronunciation.

Sometimes sentence final 'r' is dropped, subsumed into the vowel, like in British pronunciation.

Sometimes single syllables become split since Korean doesn't really do consonant clusters, so 3 syllable United becomes 5 syllable . 

Of course, non-English words may be transliterated based on native language pronunciation, as in  for Paris.

skills.name: Greetings
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Greetings**

Hello! It's nice to meet you! 

In this lesson we'll learn some basic Korean pleasantries and get our first look at how to form a Korean sentence.

####**Names**

We introduce some common Korean names here in Lesson 1.

In general, full Korean names have three syllables - a one syllable family name and a two syllable given name.  The name is written family name first and given name second, without any space in between.

For example,  would be Lee Seonhwa, or in the usual English name order Seonhwa Lee. 

We try to be generous with the alternate translations, since names generally have a lot of different spellings as some people still continue to use older forms of romanization.  However, we do NOT want you to "translate."  is not the English name Graham, and we will not accept that as a valid translation.

A lot of surnames do have "standard" translations, such as Lee for . As in the case of Lee, this may not reflect current spelling or pronunciation, but at one point in time, Lee did indeed start with a .

####**Agglutination**

Korean nouns do not decline for number, case, or gender. The noun is the noun. Period. Simpler than English. 

However, Korean is an **agglutinating** or **agglutinative** language. Rather than changing the base noun depending on its use in a sentences, extra pieces called *particles* are added to introduce more meaning. In general these pieces are added to the end of the word. 

While that may seem scary, agglutinating languages usually have very clear rules so that people don't get confused when a basic word becomes buried inside a larger piece. The same is true for Korean. This means that you don't have to worry about memorizing exceptions to the rules, like we do in English!

We'll talk more about particles as you move through the course. Our first particle here is /

####**The Topic Particle**

**/** 

 occurs after a consonant and  after a vowel. This marks the topic of the sentence. When several sentences in a row have the same topic, only the first sentence needs to have / since it will be understood that the topic is continuing. When a new topic is introduced or when contrasting (as for *X*) you add a new /.

####**Where is the subject?**

When the subject (or any other sentence component) is well implied in the context, you may freely drop it in Korean, though you will mostly see and be asked to submit full sentences here since translation exercises do not come with any context. If you come across an incomplete sentence in this course, then the dropped component is probably **people in general** (often translated to *one* or *you*) or something very obvious even without context. Otherwise we accept every possible pronoun for the omitted components.

####**Copula**

The verb ~ is the only verb that is agglutinative.

| English | Korean |
| ------------- |-------------|
| (It) is X. | X.* |
| Y is X. | Y/ X. |

In the speech level (more about that later) we're using at this point in the course, this verb will always be realized as ~ for a statement.

####**Liaison**

A short note on the liaison in ~. Although written as ip-ni-da, a  plus a nasal (//), often results in the  being pronounced as . So, here it sounds like "" despite the spelling.

####**Speech Level**

We'll talk about speech level in more detail as we go on, but for now, just know that every sentence ends in a verb and every verb has an ending that shows the speech level.

Here we have / for statements and / for questions.

* / come after vowels, so we get ~ and .

* / come after consonants, so we get .

####**Phrases**

Most pleasantries (hello, thank you, excuse me, etc) in Korean are a single word. You don't need to form a whole sentence when the listener knows what you mean, and so often just the verb is used.

####**Thank You**

There are two words for thank you, **** and ****.

In most cases, the two are interchangeable. However, , a Sino-Korean word, has a more formal connotation and is used more in public speaking (with notable exceptions including the news) while , a native Korean word, is less formal. 

In the speech level we're using now that's not an issue, but when you drop to a lower level  often takes precedence. 

**** literally means "to thank," while  is "to be thankful," so that can also lead to some differences in usage.

####**Sorry and Excuse Me**

 is a more formal form of apology. 

 is the word you'd use if you're trying to get past someone on a crowded subway or if you bump into someone.  literally means "I am being rude."

####**Nice to Meet You**

Nice to meet you, ** **, is a set phrase that literally means "Glad to have met."

####**Interrogative**

The **Interrogative** is used to ask questions. In , this mood is formed by adding **-()** to the verb stem.  Word order remains the same.

skills.name: Basics
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**To Be**

In this lessons we're going to learn how to make some sentences using the verb ~, corresponding to the English verb "to be." Let's get started!

####**Nouns**

Before we can make a sentence, first we need some nouns, so that's what we do here in Lesson 1. Nouns in Korean function much like nouns in English, so nothing too difficult.

Korean nouns do not decline for number, case, or gender. The basic noun is the basic noun. Period.  However, Korean is an **agglutinating** or **agglutinative** language. Rather than the noun changing depending on its use in a sentences, extra pieces are added to introduce more meaning.  In general these pieces are added at the end.  We will mention these chunks in more detail as they are introduced.

While that may seem scary to some of you, agglutinating languages usually have very clear rules so that people don't get confused when a basic word becomes buried inside a larger piece. The same is true for Korean. This means that you don't have to worry about memorizing exceptions to the rules, like we do in English!

Like many agglutinating languages, Korean has **vowel harmony**, with a two way split: , ,  are one set while , , , , and  form the other. See if you notice this as you go through the course.

####**And**

One common chunk is **and**.  Unlike in English, where there is one word for "and" that can function in all situations, Korean has several. We introduce two here.

Both versions are used only with nouns, in slightly different ways and with slightly different meanings.

**~** 

 can be attached to the end of any noun. The general meaning is "and," but the sub-context is that the nouns don't have any special relationship, just two things that happen to be together. 

Note: When  occurs after /// the consonant moves to replace the  while becoming stronger. For example,  is pronounced as --. In fact, /// are all designed to look like their partners with one additional line, representing this "strengthening".

**~/** 

/ function similar to one another, with  following a vowel and  a consonant. **** vs ****. / has a sub-context indicating a closer connection between the two words. 

However, in many cases both options are equally acceptable and all Korean speakers will understand what you mean if you pick the wrong one.

####**Copula**

The verb ~ in Korean is the only verb that is agglutinative.  Rather than "to be X" Korean has X. In the speech level (more about that later) we're using at this point in the course, this will always be realized as X.

####**To Not Be**

Korean has a separate verb, , that means "to not be." This verb is not agglutinative, meaning that it comes after the noun. Usually that noun is marked with /, so "Y is not X" would be Y X .

####**Liaison**

A short note on the liaison in ~. Although written as ip-ni-da, a  plus a nasal (//), often results in the  being pronounced as . So, here it sounds like "" despite the spelling.

####**Particles**

Korean has a number of particles that attach to nouns depending on their role in a sentence. We see two here: / and /

**/** 

 occurs after a consonant and  after a vowel. This marks the topic of the sentence. When several sentences in a row have the same topic, only the first sentence needs to have / since it will be understood that the topic is continuing. When a new topic is introduced or when contrasting (as for *X*) you add a new /.

**/**

  comes after a consonant and  comes after a vowel. / marks the subject of the verb, the person or thing doing the action. When the subject is also the topic of the sentence, / takes over.  A long, complicated sentence with many verbs will have many nouns marked with /, but only one marked with /.

In casual speech where the topic and subject are easy to understand, many Korean speakers drop these particles. But, until you get used to this system, make sure to include them!

####**Subject**

Unlike in English, not all sentences in Korean have a subject. If the subject is understood it is perfectly acceptable and fully correct to drop the subject.

####**Roots**

As we go through the course we'll point out some of the common word roots, which will hopefully help you reach a deeper understanding of the vocabulary. Many of these roots are Sino-Korean, so we'll sometimes include the characters.

**Note** some of us learn this way, but if this isn't for you, go ahead and ignore the Roots sections :)

* / - woman/female ()
*  - man/male ()
*  - small ()
*  - study/school ()
*  - food ()

skills.name: Intro
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Introduction**

Let's introduce ourselves a little more deeply here, focusing on nationality and occupation.  We'll also discuss Korean grammar a bit here too.

####**To Not Be**

Korean has a separate verb, , which means "not to be." This verb is not agglutinative, and it comes after the thing that the subject is not, or the **complement**. The complement particle is also /. At this point in the course, this verb will always be realized as .

| English | Korean |
| ------------- |-------------|
| (It) is not X. | X . |
| Y is not X. | Y X . |

####**Speech Level**

Korean has **7** speech levels. 

Don't let it scare you away!

Now that that fact has sunk in a little, let me alleviate your fears. Only **4** of the levels are common in daily speech today. You only hear some of the others among the older generation or in historical movies/dramas. 

Unlike in some languages where different speech levels use different words, Korean speech levels mainly just affect the endings of the verbs and the pronouns that go along with them.

We'll introduce more levels in due time. For now we're using , one of the most common levels.  This is what you'd use talking to a stranger, when doing public speaking, among coworkers, to a teacher, and to customers/clients. In some dialects, including some popular in North Korea, this form is even common in more casual conversation, especially among men.

Throughout these Tips&Notes, we usually talk about verbs in the infinitive, which always ends with ~. Everything that comes before ~ is the verb stem.

####**Chinese Loanwords**

Korean, like most languages in East Asia, has a lot of loanwords from Chinese. 

Chinese loanwords, Sino-Korean, are very pervasive.  They make up about half of Korean vocabulary. However, similar to the overwhelming amount of Latin/French based vocabulary in English, many of these words are uniquely Korean, either because of a change in meaning or because two Chinese roots were put together to make a new Korean word.

Unlike in Japanese, where one Chinese character () may have multiple pronunciations, in Korean it is more standardized.  Each  usually has one pronunciation and the conversions between Chinese and Korean follow a logical system. If you speak some Chinese, you may soon be able to guess the meanings of some Korean words.

 for example, comes from nnng, with  meaning "be safe!"  has kept the Chinese pronunciation while  has slightly changed. Most borrowings that include pinyin *-ing* have become **.

It should be noted that most of these words were initially borrowed hundreds of years ago, so they don't match Mandarin pronunciation 100%. Sometimes the Korean is closer to Cantonese or Shanghainese.

####**Person**

Korean has two words that roughly mean "person." 

Firstly is , the Native Korean word.  It the main word when you want to say "that person" or "the person who," but it can also follow the name of a country to mean "a person from country X."

Second is , the Sino-Korean word.  It is not a standalone word, but instead is agglutinative, and attaches to the word that it modifies.

Therefore both   and  mean "Korean person."  

####**Also**

The particle ~ is affixed after a noun to mean "also" or "too."  It can attach to the topic, subject, or object in the sentence, and usually takes the place of the other particles.

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | person |  |
|  | country |  |
|   | Korea |  |
|  | United Kingdom |  |
|  | United States |  |
|   | Japan |  |
|  | employee/member |  |

skills.name: Motion
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Verbs of Motion**

In this skill we introduce some verbs of motion along with the particles that go with them. 

In general the word order with these sentences is Subject-From-To-Verb.

####**Direction Particles**

| Korean | English |
| - | - |
| ~ | to (implies destination) |
| ~ | from |
| ~ (after a consonant except ) | to/toward (implies direction) |
| ~ (after a vowel or ) | to/toward (implies direction) |
| ~ | up to (implies some sort of boundary/limit) |

####**And**

There are actually several ways to say "and" in Korean.  The particles *** and **** both mean "and" and attach directly onto a noun.  (For connecting verbs, we'll learn more about that in another lesson.)

| Korean | Example | Usage |
| - | - | - |
| ~ |  |  Common in writing, after a vowel |
| ~ |  | Common in writing, after a consonant |

####**Not**

In this skill we also learn how to negate a verb.

**** is an auxiliary verb that comes after the main verb in the sentence, and conjugates just like any other verb in Korean.

 is connected to the preceding verb using ~ after the verb stem. As a result, if we wanted to say "not to go" we would get this:

 (infinitive) -  (verb stem) -  (verb stem + ) -   (negated verb, in the infinitive) -   (fully conjugated verb)

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | school/study |  |
|  | food/eating |  |
|   | room |  |
|  | room |  |
|  | exercise |  |
|  | field/location/place |  |
|  | sickness |  |
|  | institution |  |

skills.name: Sit/Stand
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Stative Verbs**

Grammatically, Korean differentiates between three main types of verbs - active, stative, and descriptive.  In this lesson we will look more at **stative verbs**, which are those verbs which indicate that the subject is in a fixed, unchanging state.  

####**Stative**

Since English doesn't do this, it may be tricky for English speakers to understanding.  But let's think about it together.

Compare "to stand up" with "to be standing." Which one is an action and which one is a state?  When you "stand up" you physically rise to your feet. You move.  But when you "are standing?" You are not taking an action, you are simply in a position that is unchanging.  This, in Korean, would be described using a stative verb.

Common stative verbs can be:

*  - to be sitting
*  - to be standing
*  - to be lying down
*  - to exist/to be present
*  -  to not exist/to not be present

####**At**

We recently learned that the particle ~ can be used with a verb of motion to indicate motion towards.  Well, when used with a stative verb it can also be used to indicate location.

This is different from the particle where an action takes place, which would be the also familiar ~, but more on that when the time comes.

| Particle | Usage |
| - | - |
| ~ | location where something static is happening |
| ~ | location where an action happening |

If you are interested, you can read Ash-Fred's comment here for further explanation about the two:

[Link](https://goo.gl/hBx4oB)

####**Word Order**

Since Korean has so many particles, it can have relatively free word order.  However, there is a general order that is often observed, especially in casual speech when particles may be dropped.

For a stative sentence, the order is usually 

**Subject - Location - Verb**

For example:

*    - The man sits in the park.
*    - The girl stands in the library.

We will continue to revisit word order as we learn new particles and see longer and longer sentences.

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | public |  |
|  | mountain |  |
|   | institute |  |
|  | book |  |
|  | education |  |
|  | room |  |

skills.name: Food
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Food**

Time to learn a little bit about the very important topic of Food!

####**Object Particle**

It is time that we learned the next of Korean's all important particles - **/**.

This particle pair is used to mark the **direct object** of the verb.  What is the direct object?  It is the thing that the subject does the verb to.  Think about it like this: Who verbs what? The "what" is the object.

As in the case of other particles, whether to use  or  depends on what sound it is following.   always follows a consonant and  always follows a vowel.

| Sentence | Translation |  |
| - | - | - |
|   . | I eat pizza. | vowel +  |
|   . | I eat fruit. | consonant +  |

####****

Rice, ****, is a staple in Korean cuisine. In fact, it isn't uncommon to say   to mean simply "to eat" rather than "to eat rice." Rice has been so important that Korean has multiple words for rice where English has only one.  means specifically **cooked rice**. 

####**Fish**

Fish is very popular in Korea, and Koreans can be very specific about what fish they are eating. In general,  is used to talk about fish as an animal and  is the fish you'd find in the grocery store.

####**Eggs**

Koreans love eggs. Not just chicken eggs, but also quail eggs and fish eggs are popular in Korean dishes. Here we've taught two words, **** and ****. Both refer specifically to chicken eggs, being combinations of **chicken** and **egg**.  is originally from Chinese, and there has been a push by some people to use only native Korean .

####**Korean Foods**

We know that Korean food has become more internationally well known in recent years, so you'll want to know all you need to get by at your favorite Korean restaurant. This lesson serves only as the first step, so we have just introduced a few of the most common basics.

* ****: ramen. You can easily find instant  in any grocery store, but even better is to go to a restaurant where the chef expertly creates a delicious bowl full of noodles, meats, and vegetables with a savory broth.

* ****: bulgogi, thinly sliced beef, seasoned, and often cooked at the table.

* ****: kimbap/gimbap, white rice and fillings rolled up inside sheets of  (seaweed laver). Unlike sushi,  fillings are usually cooked and rarely include fish, aside from canned tuna. Common ingredients include egg, daikon, carrot, cucumber, crab stick, and ham. Some more inventive  includes bulgogi, tuna salad, and spicy chicken.

* **Note** Since the Korean alphabet does not match one to one with the English alphabet, it is difficult to spell some Korean foods. When multiple spellings exist, we will accept all common spellings.

####**English Transliteration**

As Korean generally does not have consonant clusters, English words with clusters have the vowel  added when needed, like in . This also happens also when a word ends with a consonant, although ch and j sounds often wind up as  or  instead, like in .

Sometimes the letter R is simply dropped, more British style, as in .

####**Hot and Cold**

English has one word for hot and one for cold. Korean, on the other hand, makes a distinction between several different words.

**Hot**

| Korean | Explanation  |
| ---------| -----|
|  | a hot thing, usually foods and drinks, but might also be anything hot to the touch |
|  | something that makes you feel hot, like a summer day, a sauna, or a fever |

**Cold**

| Korean | Explanation  |
| ---------| -----|
|  | a cold thing, usually foods and drinks, but might also be anything cold to the touch |
|  | something that makes you feel cold, like a winter day or a freezer |

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | alcohol |  |
|  | chicken |  |
|  | noodle |  |

skills.name: Describing
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Adjectives**

Verbs are more dominant in Korean than they are in English. In fact, for the most part **adjectives** don't really exist in the language. Instead, there are **descriptive verbs**.  In most speech levels, including the one that we're using now, these verbs act exactly the same as all other verbs. 

| Korean | English  |
| ---------| -----|
|  | goes |
|  | is bad |
|  | eats |
|  |  is good |

As you can see, unlike in English, where we have to add other words in order to form a full thought using an adjective, Korean descriptive verbs are already fully loaded with "is."

####**Adjectives**

But what about using adjectives without "to be?" Using the verbal roots, there is a way to transform all Korean verbs into modifiers, which we'll introduce in the Modifiers unit. Action verbs and descriptive verbs can all undergo this process, but they do so in slightly different ways.

####**Height**

There is not really a direct translation of "tall" or "short" into Korean. However, there is an easy work around.

**** means high and ****  means low. When talking about buildings, trees, mountains, and so on, it is possible to say that something is high/low rather than tall/short.

When talking about people, you reference their height directly along with big/small.  This is usually done by marking the person in question as the topic, following by **** as the subject and then the descriptive verb, for something like this:

 **** ****.- I am short. (Literally something like: "As for me, height is small.")

When the meaning is understood, it is sometimes possible to drop the **** and just say  .    

####**Not**

In a previous skill we met the negative verb . Here we meet it's adverbial sibling ****.

The usage of  is much simpler than .  Put it right in front of the verb, and you're done!

Meaning-wise, the two are virtually indistinguishable, but  is used more often in speech, especially when speaking casually.

|  |   | English  |
| ---------| -----|-----|
|   . |   . |  I do not go.  |
|   . |   . | I am not beautiful.  |

skills.name: Actions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Action Verbs**

In this lesson we will go more in depth with action verbs. Let's go!

####****

Now we welcome back the particle **** as we learn its second meaning.

With action words ~ has the meaning of "at" or "in", similar to the particle ~ with a stative verb.

| Particle | Usage |
| - | - |
| ~ | where an action takes place |
| ~ | where something static is happening |

With some words, you can use either particle, but it changes the meaning.

*   . I sit in the park. (the state of being seating)
*   . I sit down in the park. (the act of moving into the seated position)

####**Word Order**

Although word order is not fixed, the usual word order for these sentences is Subject - Location - Object - Verb.

*    . The student writes a letter at the cafe.

####**Education**

Education is important in Korea, and families spend a lot of money each year on their children's education.  Even young children have ample extracurricular activities, including not only sports and instruments, but also additional academic classes.  These classes are often at a ****.  Often these are private institutes, but they may also be connected to a school.  English speakers in Korea refer to these as academy, institute, or hagwon.

While children spend a lot of time at the hagwon, older students and adults preparing to take college entrance exams or going through a professional or linguistic certification process spend their time at a ****.  Literally a "reading-books-room" a  may be a simple "study room" or "reading room", similar to the quiet study space you would find in a library.  You can also find a  with private rooms featuring advanced technology and complimentary refreshments.

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | book |  |
|  | store |  |
|  | water |  |
|  | reading |  |
|  | study |  |
|  | institute |  |

skills.name: This/That
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Demonstratives**

In this lesson we're going to focus on Korean demonstratives, those words we use to specify whether we're talking about **this** one or **that** one.

####**Three Way Split**

Korean has a three way split in demonstratives while English only have two, which can be confusing at first, but is easy once you get the hang of it.

| Korean | English  |
| ---------| -----|
|  | this, close to the speaker |
|  | that, close to the listener |
|  | that (over there), far from both speaker and listener |

 roughly corresponds to **yonder**.

####**This and That**

, , and  are the basic demonstratives, used just like **this** and **that** in English.

| Korean | English  |
| ---------| -----|
|   | this dog |
|   | that dog (close to the listener) |
|   | that dog (over there) |

**Note**

Since Korean has no corresponding word for *the*, it is sometimes (actually very often) impossible to tell whether it is **an** apple or **the** apple that they are talking about, from the context. Then chances are it is "an" apple, as it is normal to use **** in lieu of "the" in such cases.

| Korean | English |
| - | - |
|  | bread/the bread |
|   | that bread (close to the listener)/the bread |
|   | that bread (over there) |

, , and  are used in compound words to express other ideas. When combined with , this compound is a noun that corresponds to "this/that one" in English. It combines with particles just like any other noun.

| Korean | English  |
| ---------| -----|
|  | this one |
|  | that one |
|  | that one (over there) |

####**Here and There**

For here/there, there is a slight change in the stems, but the basic meaning stays the same.

| Korean | English  |
| ---------| -----|
|  | here |
|  | there (somewhere close to the listener) |
|  | over there |

**Note** , , and  are nouns. Most of the time, you need an adverbial particle  after them, but it is usually omitted. When they are used as nouns, they can be translated to this place, that place, and that place (over there), respectively.

####**Hot and Cold**

**Hot**

| Korean | Explanation  |
| ---------| -----|

skills.name: Language
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Language**

This lesson teaches us how to talk about language, while focusing on the grammar to propose an action.

####**Propositive**

Korean has several verbal moods depending on how the verb is used in the sentence.  While English would usually use extra words to get to the same meaning, Korean packs it all into the verb endings.

The **propositive** mood is used to make suggestions, similar to "Let's" in English. In ****, this mood is formed by adding **-()** to the verb stem.

| Stem | Ending | Example |
| - | - | - |
| Ending in a vowel | - |    |
| Ending in , with  deleted | - |    |
| Ending in a consonant bar  | - |    |
| (negative) | -  |     |

####****

As we've seen before, some of the particles have a second usage depending on the situation.  The same is true with /.

We've already learned that / means "toward" when used with a verb of motion.

The second meaning of this particle is something akin to "through," "with," or "as."  This is the **instrumental** particle.

For example:

  . I speak in Korean.

In that example, you are speaking "through" or "using" the Korean language. Make sense?

####**Speaking a Language**

When talking about speaking a language, there are two options, ~  and ~ .

| Korean | English |
| - | - |
|   | To speak Korean |
|   |  To speak in Korean |

####**Language**

Like so many other things in Korean, to form the name for a language, you follow a very regular pattern.  

Usually, just take the name of a country and add ~ or ~. 

 - /

What's the difference between the two?  For the most part, they are the same.  But  sounds a bit more like the spoken language while  sounds bigger, including reading, writing, speaking, and listening.

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | speech |  |
|  | words |  |
|  | writing | - |
|  | every |  |
|  | day |  |

skills.name: Animals 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Animals**

Time to learn some animal related vocab and how to give an order.

####**Imperative**

Korean has several verbal moods depending on how the verb is used in the sentence.  While English would usually use extra words to get to the same meaning, Korean packs it all into the verb endings.

The **imperative** mood is used to give orders. In , this is formed by taking the verb stem and adding -(). There is no word corresponding to *please* in Korean. Both answers with or without *please* will be accepted, and you may ignore *please* in reverse translations.

| Stem | Ending | Example |
| - | - | - |
| Ending in a vowel | - |    |
| Ending in , with  deleted | - |    |
| Ending in a consonant other than  | - |    |
| (negative) | -  |     |

The **negative imperative** mood is formed by adding **- ** to the verb stem before conjugation, giving us  ,  , and  , here in .

####**To Ride**

**** in Korean means "to ride." This is the same for an animal as it is for a vehicle. It can also be translated as "to take" as in "I take the bus to school."

####**Korean Animals**

We introduce some animals throughout the course that are not as well known as some of the others, but are common in Korea. Here we meet the the .

**** is a magpie, a type of black and white bird similar to a raven or a crow. They are fairly common throughout Korea, even in urban areas.

####**~**

There are many animals in Korean that end with ~.

This happens in part because of another piece of Korean grammar. Nouns ending with ~ are similar to nouns ending in -er in English, meaning "the one that does X." For example,  "elephant" comes from  +  + , or the "long-noser".

An exception is , which was formed by the  from / becoming permanently attached to the original form of the noun, possibly. Both  and  are still in common usage.

####**Rat/Mouse**

Languages group things differently. One example in Korean is ****, which can mean both rat and mouse. If you want to be more specific, **** means "mouse" only. 

####****

**** is a gender-neutral term for a single animal of the bovine species. *Ox*, *cow*, and *bull* are all accepted as a translation.

####**Fish**

Unlike in English, where fish can be both the animal and the meat, Korean has two different words. However, it isn't as cut and dry as the difference between "cow" and "beef".

**,** which we've already learned, means "fish" in terms of food. This may be a piece of cooked fish, a whole fish, or even a live fish waiting to be sold from a tank at a fish market.

**** (literally "water" + "meat") refers to a fish as a living animal, usually not as something intended to be eaten.

####**/**

The topic particle **/** can also come after an adverb or an adverbial phrase.

| Example | Translation |
| - | - |
| ****  . | There are many people in Seoul. |

**/** still means *regarding* though it would be ungrammatical in English to say *regarding in Seoul*. Since *regarding Seoul* would also work fine, you may just say "****  ."

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | nose |  |
|  | fish |  |
|  | agriculture |  |
|  | tiger|  |
|  | sheep |  |

skills.name: Questions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Asking Questions**

We've already covered questions in "Greetings," but let's go into more detail now.

####**Interrogative**

The **Interrogative** mood is used to ask questions. In , this mood is formed by adding **-()** to the verb stem.

| Stem | Ending | Example |
| - | - | - |
| Ending in a vowel | - |    |
| Ending in , with  deleted | - |    |
| Ending in a consonant | - |    |
| (negative) | -  |     |

The **negative interrogative** mood is **not** formed with - , but with **- ** like the negative declarative mood.

**Note**

While  is simply the negation of a verb,  means the speaker does not allow the listener(s) to do something. You may consider the propositive mood as the first person plural imperative mood here.

####**Questions Words**

Unlike in English, word order does not have to change when asking a question. Question words can simply go into the sentence where the word they replace would have been. Just like declarative (or any other) sentences, it is possible to move the question words for emphasis.

| Korean | English | Note |
| - | - | - |
|  | when |  |
|  | where | Unlike English,  is not an adverb itself, but a pronoun. Thus it is often used with  or . |
|  | who |  and  (subject particle) are usually contracted to **** in spoken language. |
|  | what (pronoun) |  is often contracted to **** in spoken language. As  is also often contracted to , you may say  for . |
|  | what (determiner) | As in "what animal" or "what country";  is sometimes contracted to **** in spoken language. |
|  | what kind of |  replaces an adjective. |
|  | which |  |
|  | how | Formed from **** meaning *to be how* |
|  | why |  |
| / | how much | "" on its own is usually used to asking prices, while "" is used to ask "how + adjective" |

skills.name: Split Verbs
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Split Verbs**

####**To Do + Noun**

A lot of verbs can be broken up into two pieces. For example,  means *a song*, and  means *to do*, and they form a new word "", "to sing." You can, of course, say   (lit. to do a song). 

Many of these nouns are borrowed from Chinese or English, as adding  is the best way to adapt a foreign word to serve as a Korean verb.

####**Reduplication**

There are some special verbs that are repetitive to the eye/ears of an English speaker.

These verbs often add the noun ahead of the verb, either as one word, or as two words with the noun marked with /.

| Verb | (broken into) | English |
| - | - | - |
|  |   | to sleep (a sleep) |
|  |   | to dance (a dance) |
|  |   | to dream (a dream) |

 can stand alone without , but  or  always needs an object.

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
| ~ | ~ly |  |
| ~ | ~ly |  |
|  | person |  |
|  | matter/affair |  |

skills.name: Animals 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Animals 2**

####**To Find**

**** can be both "to find" and "to search/to look for." Generally, it can be understood from context which of the two is meant. One hint that works some of the time is simple present vs present progressive ( vs  ) something like "to find" vs "to be finding."

**** is a tanuki/mangut/raccoon dog, depending on the translation. They are small raccoon-like animal more closely related to the fox that can be found throughout East Asia. Sometimes  may also be used to mean simply raccoon.

####****

Just like rat/mouse in English, Korean has two words for owl. **** is an owl with ear tufts, like Duo. **** is an owl without tufted ears. 

####**Onomatopoeia**

Quite a few Korean animals end with ~.  Why is that? 
 It's because that ending can mean ~er.  For example  comes from +, which would be like if the word for "frog" was "ribbit-er."  could also be translated to something like "hoot-er."

####****

The word **** is another way to make a negative sentence, indicating the inability to do something.

  /  = Not to exercise

  =To be unable to exercise/cannot exercise

 may imply that the inability is due to the person's own inferiority, that they are simply not up to the task of completing the verb.

Often  is used together with , as in    . "I cannot sing well"  

There is another way to say "unable" that we will introduce later.

|  | hoot |  |
|  | croak/ribbit |  |
|  | dragon |  |

skills.name: Giving
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Giving**

####**Forms of Address**

Korean has a complicated system for forms of address. You should not call a stranger, superior, or an elder only by their name.  is commonly used in translations, but is not common in spoken Korean. People will usually use the title or status of the person as a form of address, followed by **-** (without a space). For example, in a store, customers are often referred to as  (customer/guest + -). When the person is much older than you, you could also say  (lit. teacher; not just in a store but at any time). When speaking to someone politely in a situation where their name must be used, such as in a store or airport calling someone by name over a loudspeaker, it is common to add  after their name (with a space).

In short, you can't really translate *you* into Korean; *you* could be mom, teacher, driver, pastor, or anything. Furthermore, some nouns, such as *singer* (), sound weird when followed by -. As you may or may not imagine, there are really some times when we Koreans avoid talking just because we don't know how to address someone. Anyway, since it is practically impossible for us to add every single title or status as an accepted answer for *you*, only title-neutral pronouns such as , ,  (introduced later), etc. will be accepted in English-to-Korean exercises. (You will eventually have to get used to how to call someone outside Duolingo or any online materials.) In Korean-to-English exercises, if a title is used in lieu of the second person pronoun, translate it as *you*.

skills.name: Meals
skills.tipsAndNotes:
####**Meals**

In Korean the names of meals mirror the times of day. ** ** is literally the "morning meal." However, in everyday speech people drop the .

####**A Korean Meal**

In Korea, meals are usually served family style in the middle of the table. Also in the center are smaller dishes of ****, side dishes. Kimchi is the most famous , and comes in dozens of varieties. But, side dishes can also include things like potato salad, Korean pancakes, and steamed egg.

####****

Most of the fruits and vegetables popular in Korea are popular around the world. One specialty in Korea that we couldn't fail to mention here is ****, which can be satsuma, tangerine, or mandarin, depending on the translation. In any case, they are small, juicy oranges. In Korea you can find  on many menus, as juice, as candy, in chocolate, or just fresh as dessert.

####****

The particle **** means *only*. The topic, subject, and object particles come after it.

####**Hungry/Thirsty**

In Korea, you do not say that you are hungry or thirsty, but    or   . Literally, this means "My stomach is hungry" and "My throat is dry."

####****

There is no exact translation for this word in English. Snacks are not necessarily , and crackers are only a kind of . So here's the definition.

* ****: chicken? Actually this is fried chicken, which Korea has made its own. Fried chicken in Korea is something you cannot miss! Usually in a sauce, most commonly garlic, soy sauce, and a type of spicy bbq.

* ****: chicken and beer. A common pairing. You probably won't find this word in the dictionary because it is just a combination of  and .

* ****: kimchi, preserved vegetables. Most people think of spicy fermented cabbage, but that's just one type of kimchi. Some kimchi is cabbage, but there are also radish, scallion, and cucumber kimchis. Some are spicy, but some are salty or vinegary.

* ****: laver, dried seaweed sheets. In Korea you can get a small packet of  to eat on its own or with white rice.

skills.name: Colors
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Colors**

Colors can be tricky in Korean, with a mixture of Native Korean and Sino-Korean color terms.

####**Native Korean**

In Lesson 1 we introduce some Native Korean verbal modifiers. 

|    English    | Korean           |
| ------------- |-------------|
| Black  |  |
| White |  |
| Blue |  | 
| Red  |  |
| Yellow  |  |

As you should be able to see, all of these are the Modifier forms of descriptive verbs.

Sometimes these adjectives are followed by  "color" with or without  ~, the Modifier form of ~.

So for "black cat" you may see:

*   
*  
*  

####**Sino-Korean**

In Lesson 2 we introduce some Sino-Korean colors. Like most borrowings from Chinese, these take the form of nouns in Korean.

|    English    | Korean           |
| ------------- |-------------|
| Orange  |  |
| Green | / |
| Gray |  | 
| Brown  |  |
| Purple  |  |
| Pink  |  |

Usually these are used with / to form modifiers in a sentence.

An "orange cat" gives us:

*  
*  

Most colors have a Sino-Korean equivalent, but normally Korean colors take precedence, with the Sino-Korean words used as roots in compound words.

####**Green**

Korean colors are a bit more nuanced than the ones we use in English. Many colors have multiple words that can be used to mean the same thing but with different connotations.

The one case where we do introduce both words here is "green." Both  and  mean green, so what's the different?

 means "grass green" and may have the connotation of being cleaner or sharper than .

The same is true for  (pure white) and  (jet black). We'll may see some of these colors later in the course, but for know you can just put them out of your mind. 

####**Color Nouns**

The Native Korean colors have noun forms based in part on their base verb forms. 

|    English    | Modifier    | Noun         |
| ------------- |-------------|------------|
| Black  |  |  |
| White |  |  |
| Blue |  |  |
| Red  |  |  |
| Yellow  |  |  |

While these may sometimes be used to form modifiers, usually they are used in compound nouns or when talking about the color itself.

One compound we'll see here is  (bluebird) compared to   (blue bird).

In this skill we also introduce .  is used as "color" when standing alone, while  is most commonly used as a suffix attached to other words. One exception to this is when asking what color something is, which is usually realized as "X  ?" 

####**Descriptive Verbs**

The Native Korean colors have descriptive verbs that may used for "to be X-color."

|    English    | Modifier    | Noun         | Verb        |
| ------------- |-------------|------------|---------|
| Black  |  |  |  |
| White |  |  |  |
| Blue |  |  |  |
| Red  |  |  |  |
| Yellow  |  |  |  |

~ verbs form a special case for conjugation, as we saw in Polite Moods with . Drop the  and the  turns into . For ,  becomes .

The cat is white= .

When using Sino-Korean colors, or even the Native Korean modifiers, it is common to use ~ to form the descriptive verb.

The cat is gray= .

####**But**

There are two ways to say "but" in Korean. First we will discuss **~**.

* ~ is the closest the the English "but." It is attached directly to the verb stem, and indicated a contrast between the two clauses.

   .=>I do not eat, but I do drink.

Stand alone form:  (more colloquial)/

skills.tipsAndNotes:
####****

 means *more* as in *small**er** *or* **more** beautiful*, but given context it can be dropped in Korean. For example, " ." could mean "I am faster (than my brother)." But please do not leave it out in this course unless a proper context is given.

skills.name: Positions
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Positions**

Let's learn Korean prepositions!

####**Prepositions**

English prepositions, words like on, in, and between form their own class of words. In Korean they are actually regular nouns, taking particles depending on their use in the sentence.

Generally speaking, "prepositions" in Korean act like postpositions, coming after the noun, usually with the particle  or .

*  =inside the house

Strictly speaking, there should be an  after the first noun.

*  

Grammatically, this means that a direct translation would actually be "at the house's inside" rather than "inside the house." In normal usage, the  dropped.

| Korean | English |
| ------------- |-------------|
|  | in/inside |
|  | outside |
|  | in front |
|  | next to |
|  | over/on/above |
|  | behind |
|  | under/beneath |
|  | under/beneath |
|  | inside/among |
|  | in the middle |
|  | between |
|  | near |
|  | across from |
|  | left |
|  | right |

####**On**

**** means both "on" and "above." In many cases, when the meaning of "on" would otherwise be understood, it is not necessary to use "." Just the particle "" would be enough.

"" is not used for something "on" the wall, since  carries the connotation of behind "above" something.

When we want to specifically say "on" vs "over/above" we add , which means directly. **** can be used with most of these position words.

####**Under**

While  and  can both be translated to "under", they are fairly different in meaning.  refers to the whole space lower than a standard point which could be anything (e.g. sunshine, moonlight, the sky, the sea level, etc.), but  means either  or the bottom, of a tangible object.   can mean either "under the car" (= ) or "the bottom of the car" which might actually be the upper part if the car is turned over, depending on the context.

*  ****  Under the sky
*   **** .  Fish live at the bottom/lower part of the sea.
*   **** .  Fish live literally under the sea; in the crust, mantle or core of the earth.
*  **/**  .  There is a key under the chair.

####**In**

Both  and  are "in(side)" in English, but they are not the same in Korean.  means what is inside or surrounded whereas  just means the inner space as opposed to the outer space.

*  ****  inside of the egg or what is inside the egg (as opposed to the shell of the egg)
*  ****  inside of the egg (as opposed to the outer space of the egg)
*  ****  inside of the building (as opposed to the exterior of the building)
*  ****  inside of the building (as opposed to outside of the building)
*  ****  inside of the mountain
* ****  in the mountains

 is an exception and is considered as one word.

If you don't know which to use, probably they are interchangeable for the word. How you see the object in your mind may affect the choice.

*  **/**  inside the box

####**And**

We're already learned / for **and**, but that pair only works to link nouns. When you want to link verbs, Korean has the suffix **~**. 

~ is attached to the stem of the verb.

  => I eat and drink.

Stand alone form: ****.

####**Table**

Korean has a few words for "table". We've already seen , and here we introduce . A  is a dining/kitchen table, composed of the words /food and /table.

####**Roots**

*  - box ()
*  - chair ()
*  - silver ()
*  - business ()

skills.name: Modifiers 1
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Verbal Modifiers**

Let's learn how to use verbs to create **modifiers** for nouns.

####**Modifiers**

As we've mentioned before, verbs play a significant role in Korean. So far we've focused on sentences like "The man goes." or "The man is bad." In this skill we'll learn how to say "The man who goes" and "The bad man."

These verbal modifiers are created using the verb stem and usually go in front of the noun, like adjectives do in English.

The process is similar, though slightly different, for descriptive and action verbs. Action verbs have three different forms (past, present, and future) and descriptive verbs have two (future and present). Here we'll focus on the present tense.

####**Descriptive Verbs**

First we'll tackle descriptive verbs. (, , and verbs that end with  or  are exceptions. They conjugate like action verbs here; see below.)

1. For a basic **descriptive verb** ending in a consonant we take the verb stem and add -.

  

2. For a basic descriptive verb ending in a vowel, you simply add - at the end of the syllable.

  

3. For a descriptive verb ending in a , the  is simply replaced by the .

  

4. For a -irregular descriptive verb, the  changes to , just as we introduced in **Polite Speech** skill. The  is then added to the end of the new stem.

  

####**Verbs**

**Action verbs** as well as  and  are much more straightforward to turn into modifiers than descriptive verbs. Simply take the verb stem and add -.

*   

*   

*   

*   

A verb stem ending in  will drop the .

*   

This modifier can be translated in multiple ways in English, often as "doing" or "who/that/which is doing."

*  : The eating person/The person who is eating

However, it could be literally anything. In English we have which, who, where, when, whose, with which, etc., but they all can be translated to -() or -. If a sentence in the present tense modifies a noun, you can use it.

*   : The sandwich **which** I am eating

*   : Korea **where** food is delicious

*   : A man **whose** hand is big

*   : A bowl **with which** (one) eats rice (*or* A bowl **that** eats rice (?))

####****

***n.*** having a higher or stronger degree than anything/anyone else

 is used to make the superlative form of a descriptive verb, and is usually translated to *the most*. However, there is a slight difference between English and Korean here. By definition, only one of the group can receive the honorable title "". If there are two tallest people in the world of the exactly same height, there is no **** tall person.

skills.name: Commands
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Polite Commands**

Moods in  are much simpler than in . Let's get started!

####**Imperative**

To form the imperative in  you need to start with the verb stem and add ().

As you may now be used to, how this works depends on whether the stem ends with a vowel or a consonant.  

* After a vowel, add -: 
* After a consonant except , add -: 
* When the last consonant is a , drop it and add : 

By dropping the , verbs like  and  have the same imperative form, . The meaning is therefore derived from context.

Note: The usual declarative ending -/- can be used in lieu of -(), but it is less formal.


####****

The primary meaning of the verb **** is "to go," but it implies the person goes to the place regularly or frequently and has something to do there. Figuratively you can say  for your workplace or school. "  ." would most likely mean you attend school (as opposed to you just go there frequently), and you can also say that when you are asked what your job is. This verb can be transitive and intransitive, and it takes () and  as a particle after the place, respectively.

skills.name: Daily Life
skills.tipsAndNotes:
####**And then**

Another suffix that can be translated as "and" is **~**. Unlike ~, ~ implies sequence of events. It can also be translated as "and so" or "and then."

To attach ~, take the  form of the verb, drop the  and attach ~. 

  .=> I eat and drink/I eat and then I drink.

Note: This form is **not** attached to a verb conjugated for tense. The tense is indicated by the final verb.

Stand alone form: ****

skills.name: Family
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Family**

Family in Korean, like in many Asian languages, is a tricky subject. Depending on age and formality, many words exist where in English there would just be one. We'll try to make it fairly straightforward for you :)

####**~**

As we saw in Honorifics with grandparent terms, many familial terms take the ending ~ with a slight change of the root word to add extra respect for the family member.

|  Plain  | Honorific |
| ------------- |-------------|
|   |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |
|  |  |

####**Older/Younger**

Age is important in determining hierarchy and respect in Korean society. 

One example is  for "my." When talking about something important, usually shared in common by a community, like your country, president, or school, Koreans usually say  to mean "my" as a sign of respect.  The same is true with parents and older relatives, as well as sometimes children. When you want to emphasis "our" over "my" you just add  to erase the confusion.

Another example is siblings, which has 6 words where English would have only 2.  The name you use for a sibling depends on your gender, their gender, and who's older.

|  Speaker's Gender  | Older Sister | Older Brother | Younger Sister | Younger Brother |
| ------------- |-------------| | | |
| Male |  |  | () | () |
| Female |  |  | () | () |

You would only ever call an older sibling  or , and never their name. The same is true for older cousins and older friends. Which certainly takes some getting used to. If we knew your brother's name then we'd add his name as a translation for , but that's sadly impossible, so please write *brother* as a translation for  though in reality you never call your brother *brother*. The same goes for , and so on.

####**If**

"If" in Korean is marked by **~()**. This suffix is added to the base verb stem. ~ follows stems ending in a vowel or a . ~ follows stems ending in a consonant.

  .=> If I eat, I drink.

####**When**

"When," "while," or "as" is marked by **~()**. ~() is attached to the stem in the same way as ~() above.

In formal writing, ~() may be written as ~().

  .=> I drink when/while/as I eat.

####**Usage**

Every Korean sentence changes based on two factors: the **listener** and the **subject**.

The listener dictates the speech level, which we've already seen.

The subject dictates the use of honorifics.

These two are mutually exclusive. Honorifics can be used in any of the speech levels of Korean, creating a very, very wide variety of sentences.

The honorific is usually seen on the verb, just like speech levels, but there are also some special honorific nouns and particles.

Honorifics are usually used when talking about older relatives, people of higher social status, deities, and other respected entities, implying that the speaker is lower in status and therefore showing honor and respect for the subject.

It would be incredibly rude to use this form in any way to refer to yourself.

####**~**

Usually the honorific is formed simply by adding **~** to the verb stem, after applying the special cases (ie =>, =>, etc). 

Form most verbs ending in a consonant, drop ~ and add ~.
=>

With a verb stem ending in a , drop the  as well.
=>

 special case verbs do not drop the , but instead act like a regular consonant.
=>

For a verb ending in a vowel, simply add ~.
=>

~ is slightly irregular, but works similar to other verbs.

|    |  |
| ------------- |-------------|
|   |  |
|  |  |
|  |  | 
|  |  |

If some of this looks familiar, it's because you've already seen ~ in the imperative. 

####**Special Verbs**

Rather than simply add ~, some verbs have their own honorific forms.

|  Plain  | Honorific |
| ------------- |-------------|
|   |  |
|  |  |
|  | * | 
|  |  |
|  |  |

In addition, the verb  replaces  when giving something to an honored person.

* replaces  only in the sense of "to be" or "to exist." The sense of "to have" can be formed using .  is still used when forming the progressive (~ing) form of the verb.

####**Other Special Words**

Other words also have their own forms.

|  Plain  | Honorific |

|   |  |

|  |  | 
|  |  |
|  (age) |  |

####**Forms of Address**

Korean forms of address are a type of honorific. 

~ is a lower level honorific usually added to somebody's name.

~ is a higher level of addressed usually added to somebody's title or to a relationship term.  With relationship terms, there is sometimes a slight change to the original when adding the stem.

skills.name: Colors 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Colors 2**

As such a verb heavy language, Korean has a large number of adverbs. We've split them between several skills, here focusing on adverbs of degree.

####**Adverbs**

Korean adverbs come before the verb.

When given the option between an adjective describing a noun or an adverb on the verb, Korean will use the adverb more often than we do in English. For example, to say "He reads many books" rather than the direct translation "   ," the correct sentence would be "   "

####**Superlative**

The **superlative** form in Korean is formed using  or  plus the adjective/descriptive verb. Both can be used interchangeably, but **** means "the most," and **** means "number one."

Usually the phrase is / + Modifier form + Noun.

For example,   =the most delicious food

When forming a superlative in English, the noun is not always used, for example "This book is the best." In Korean, you would translate that as **    ** "This book is the best book" or **    ** "This book is the best one." Unlike in English where we actively seek to avoid repeating the noun, it is completely okay in Korean.

####**Comparative**

**Comparative** in Korean is introduced with the particle ****.  can be translated as "than" and attaches to the end of the noun to which the first noun is being compared and usually comes right before the descriptive verb.

  **** .

This apple is more delicious **than** the banana.

Just using  is enough to indicate the comparative form, but  is sometimes added before the descriptive verb for emphasis. Like English, the  part can be omitted and simply adding  before the descriptive verb is enough.

   .

This apple is more delicious.

Note: Of course, you can change the word order. Since the topic normally comes first, when  comes first instead, the other noun is usually followed by () rather than (). Whether the word order is changed or not, () emphasizes the noun before it.


####**Negative*

There are some interesting adverbs that have a negative meaning in Korean that deserve special mention.

* **** means "not really/not particularly" and is usually used alongside the negated form of the verb. 

  .=It is not too good/It is not very good.

 .=There is not much.

* **** means "almost" and can be used either negatively or positively. It is mentioned here to contrast with  above.

 =There is almost nothing.

* **** means "so" or "that" and is used with negated or interrogative forms.

   .=She is not [so/that] bad.
  ?=Is it that bad?

####**Roots**

*  - number one ()
*  - special ()
*  - quite ()
*  - imposing ()
* - - -ly

skills.name: Clothing
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Clothing**

In this lesson about clothing the grammar and vocabulary are fairly straightforward, though there are some verb issues to contend with. Here we go!

####**To Put On**

Korean has multiple words meaning "to put on," each with their own distinct though potentially overlapping meanings.

Depending on context, these words can mean "to put on," "to wear," or "to be wearing."

|    Verb     | Meaning           | Types of Clothing  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | To wear/to slip on | General clothing |
|  | To wear footwear | Socks, shoes |
|  |  To wear on the head  | Hat, glasses |
|  | To wear on the hand | Gloves, ring |
|  | To wear/clasp | Belt, watch, earrings |
|  |  To wrap/tie | Tie, scarf, necklace, shoelaces |

Some other verbs may be used in very limited cases, so we will not introduce them here.

####**To Take Off**

In the same way, there are multiple ways to say "to take off." although in a more limited way.

|    Verb     | Meaning           | Types of Clothing  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | To take off/remove | General clothing, shoes, hats |
|  | To untie/unwrap | Scarf, tie, watch, belt |
|  |  To pull off/out | Gloves, belt, ring, watch |

Another one or two verbs, such as  (to detach) may also be used in other limited cases.

####**~**

By adding **~** in front of  we get  "to change clothes." 

~ also works this way for  "to transfer bus/train/plane"

####**Hanbok**

Korean traditional clothing is the hanbok, which originated in the Joseon dynasty. Hanbok is more a style of clothing than an article, usually composed of several pieces with bright colors and simple lines. People today still wear hanbok, although usually on ceremonial occasions such as weddings and certain holidays.

####** and **

So  and  both mean shoes, but while  is a general term,  is more for dress shoes.

####**Belt**

In Korean belt can be either  or , but while  is only a piece of clothing,  can also be a piece of machinery.

####**Counters**

*  - set of clothing
*  - one half of a pair
*  - a pair

####****

The verb **** has many uses and meanings in Korean.  It can serve as "to become", "to turn", or "to be."

In this lesson we see X  . This literally means "If you do X, it is not becoming." In plainer English, this would be "doing X is not okay." You can also say this in the positive, X  "doing X is okay."

Sometimes we translate this as "it is okay/it is not okay" or "it is allowed/it is not allowed", but also "you should/you should not", "you can/you cannot", or "you may/you may not." This is **not** imperative, so it will not be translated as "Do not do X."  

####**Roots**

*  - Western ()
*  - clothing ()
*  - shoes ()
*  - eye ()
*  - lens ()
*  -waist
*  -belt
*  - wrist
*  - clock ()
*  - one piece (dress)

skills.name: Past Tense
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Past Tense**

Now that we've learned four different ways for form the present tense, here we go into the past.

####**Formation**

All Korean speech levels are formed from the / form we learned in Casual. We then add ~ to the end of the syllable, giving us / as the basic past tense verb stem. Vowel harmony ends here, and the double  is followed by the vowel .

|  | Formal | Polite | Casual| Written |
|:----------|-----------|---|---|---:|
| Statement |  |  |  |  |
| Question |  |  |  | / |

####**Usage Differences**

There are a number of instances where in English we would use present but in Korean the past. Here we have  and . 

In both these cases, these verbs describe something that has already happened. With exact translation, rather than saying "someone is ugly" Korean translates as "someone was poorly formed" and instead of "something is old" Korean has "something has become old." 

####**But**

There are two ways to realize "but" in Korean. First we will discuss **~**.

* ~ is the closest the the English "but." It is attached directly to the verb stem, and indicated a contrast between the two clauses.

   .=>I do not eat, but I do drink.

Stand alone form:  (more colloquial)/

*  **~** is a bit trickier. This conjunction is not quite like any conjunction we have in English. The basic idea is that the first clause introduces background information for the second. Often, this is a contrast, and so we translate it as "but." Sometimes, however, it is simply indicating that the two are connected, and it can be translated as "and." In its stand alone form, it may be translated as "by the way."

~ is attached to action verb stems and ~ to descriptive verbs.

   .=> I eat, but I do not drink.

  , => I went to Korea and it was fun.

Stand alone form: / (spoken)

####**Roots**

*  - disease ()
*  - place ()
*  - practice ()

skills.name: Continuous
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Continuous Verbs**

In this lesson we'll do some review of the verbs we already know while introducing the **Continuous** aspect of Korean verbs.

The use of this verbal aspect is more restrictive than in English, in the present tense focusing only on verbs currently in progress. Even then, in many cases it is used more for emphasis than the English equivalent, with the simple present tense usually taking precedence. 

####**Action Verbs**

Let's start off with action verbs. Take the verb stem (root minus ~) and add ~ . ~  conjugates just like the  we've already learned, and it's as simple as that!

=> 

   =I am eating fried chicken

####**Stative Verbs**

Stative verbs like  or  take the continuous differently.  Of course, it is possible to say  , although this would translate more closely to "I am being seated" than "I am sitting."

To truly say "I am sitting" you would say   .

The rule here s to take the Casual form and add . In grammar books this may be written as / .

####**To Have**

We mentioned when introducing the possessive aspect of  that there are other ways to indicate the possessive in Korean. Here we teach the verbs  (sometimes ) and , with  the more common of the two.

Both these verbs can be translated as "to hold" or "to carry."  additionally can mean "to pick up" or "to take in hand."

In the continuous aspect, both these verbs become "to have." This is more specific, and restrictive, than using .

While "A B " in general indicated that A possesses B, "A B  " implies that A is carrying around B. This makes sense if it's something in your bag or your pocket, but it makes less sense when you're talking about your house or your friend.

####****

 means "teacher" in Korean, but is also a common term of respect. It is not uncommon for strangers to call each other  on the streets in polite conversation when they do not know which other term of address would be most appropriate. Additionally, it is sometimes added to the end of other titles, like doctor, to convey a deeper level of respect.

Students in school generally address their teachers solely as .

As the term is respectful, there is a more informal version that students use when they are talking to a favorite teacher, , which is a slang abbreviation of ()()().

skills.name: Seasons
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Seasons**

Korea has four different seasons. Let's take a look at what those seasons are like.

####**Spring**

* -Just like in Japan and Washington DC, cherry blossoms are a thing in Korea. They're beautiful.

* -This word is often used to describe baby animals.   is bear cub, for example. A puppy, though, is . Don't combine dog+baby, just don't. You'll probably end up in the ER by 5 minutes.

* -Blue or green? In the past, the basic terms in Korean didn't differentiate between the two. Just one word, , meant the both. Similar to how light blue and dark blue are both blue, but other languages might have separate words. This means that the sky, water, and grass can all be .

####**Summer**

* -Every year in summer clouds of yellow dust blow into Korea from the Gobi Desert in China. It creates a haze and leaves a film on many things. There are good days and bad days, and some with no  at all.

* -We've already seen  in Time. The use of  as 'year' is based on its original meaning of 'sun'

* -This is a type of beach, specifically the one where you go to swim or sunbathe

####**Fall**

* -This comes from Chinese characters and means specifically fallen leaves.

* -It makes some sense, but the word for "rake" is also means "scratch." It may be combined with  to form  "to rake up"

####**Winter**

* -This means specifically that something burns, and not that someone burns something.

####****

As explained earlier,  means the time period of the preceded noun or phrase. With a phrase or a sentence, just like when qualifying any other nouns in the present tense, the ending of the verb becomes -.  Note that, while  is usually translated to *during* or *while*, it is a noun in Korean. Unlike English, since Korean uses relative tense, the preceding verb is always in the present tense. Descriptive verbs except  and  cannot be used with .

| Example | Translation |
| - | - |
|   | during the summer |
|    | while eating an apple |
|     | while I am here |

####**To Go To**

**~()** means "in order to" and is only used to connect an action with a verb of motion. It indicates that you are going somewhere in order to complete an action. 

~ is attached to verb stems ending in consonants and ~ to vowels.

   .=> I go to the restaurant to eat.

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | yellow |  |
|  | sand |  |
|  | seawater |  |
|  | fallen leave |  |

skills.name: Compounds
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Compound Verbs**

As we've already seen, Korean verbs have aspects of meaning absent from their English counterparts. Here we'll introduce another level of meaning to improve your Korean fluency.

####**~**

First up is **~**.  (to give) attaches directly to the Casual form of the verb, sometimes called the / form in grammar books.

Taking it's meaning from "to give", V/ implies that the action is being done for the benefit of someone else. Sometimes this aspect of generosity is translated into English, but more often than not it isn't.

  =We read to the man.

=Eat it (for me).

####**~**

Next we have **~**.  (to see) attaches to the Casual / form as well.

Stemming from the meaning of "to see," V/ has the meaning of to try something out, to see how it is.  Both  and  can mean "to try" or "to taste," literally "to see what it's like to eat" and "to see what it's like to drink"

=Read it/Take a look at it

=Give it a try

####**~**

Now let's look at **~**. While ~ and ~ can attach to most any word, ~ is more restricted. Usually this compound ending attaches to the / form of descriptive verbs.

In fact, we've already seen this a few times, with words like  and .

Adding V/ means to treat something a certain way. For example,  ="good" and ="to like" (to treat something like it is good).

It can also mean "to act like..." For example, ="to be sad" while ="to act sad." Usually this aspect of ~ compound verbs is only used when talking in the third person because it is something that you have observed. When talking about yourself, you would just say that you were sad, not that you were acting sad.

=to be scary

=to fear

####**~/~**

Finally we have **~** and **~**, which you should recognize as "to go" and "to come." 

Coming after V/, this pair of endings is usually used with verbs of motion to indicate direction. For example, ="to move downward" so ="to come down" and ="to go down."

=to return

=to come back

=to go back

####**To Want**

We've already taught you  as "to want something" and now here we have **~ ** "to want to do something."

~  attaches to the verb stem (V minus ), and is treated as a descriptive verb. When talking about a third person, you would only ever use the compound **~ **.

  =I want to go

  =She wants to go

####**Roots**

 - ghost ()

skills.name: Numbers 2
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Sino-Korean Numbers**

Here we have the other half of the Korean number system, the Sino-Korean numbers.

####**Usage**

Sino-Korean numbers are used for dates, money, phone numbers, addresses, and in math, as well as in large numbers.

####**Six**

The number 6 in Sino-Korean is , but is  in North Korean.  In South Korea the  pronunciation was lost and the  was replaced with , but there is still a ghost of  left behind.

For the number 16, , the deleted  reacts with the  and the word is pronounced .

####**Phone Numbers**

In Korean the dashes/spaces in a phone number are read as . So 010-723-6045 would be read   .

####**Counters**

When Sino-Korean numbers are used with nouns, those nouns often double as counters. Two dollars is   not   . 

####**Big Numbers**

Once you reach 100, Sino-Korean takes over completely from Native Korean. Which is good, since Korean numbers are complicated.

Korean numbers follow the general East Asian number pattern. Instead of base 1000 like English, the base in Korean is 10 thousand.

This will take some getting used to, but 100 thousand is actually 10*10,000.

After , we have  (100 million) and  (1 trillion). Each number has four more zeroes than the number before.

skills.name: Gerund
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Gerund**

Generally speaking, a **gerund** is the ~ing form of a verb, a verbal noun. 

Korean has two ways of forming what would be a gerund in English, with overlapping but slightly different uses.

####** **

The most popular form is the present tense modifier (V) plus . 

This form is the more common in speaking.

  has a connotation of an ongoing action, not just "doing" but "the act of doing."

Just like in other circumstances,  can be abbreviated or contracted to , , , .

####****

The second form is made by taking the verb stem (V) plus .

This form may sometimes be more formal.

 has a more general connotation, "doing," and may be more abstract or impersonal.

To say "before doing X" we use this form, saying X .

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | before |  |
|  | plan |  |
|  | travel |  |
|  | important |  |

skills.name: Time
skills.tipsAndNotes:
###**Telling Time**

Here we talk about numbering hours, days, months, and years, but we won't get in to dates or days of the week until later.

####**Hours**

Telling time requires a mixture of Sino-Korean and Native Korean numbers.

* Native Korean is used with the hour, 1:00= 

* Minutes and seconds take Sino-Korean, 2:30=    

*  (afternoon) or  (before noon) can come before the time to  indicate AM or PM

* Similarly the period of the day comes before the time, 11 at night=  

* When counting hours, use  with Native Korean numbers

 =1:00
 =1 hour

####**Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow**

| Korean | English |
|:----------|-----------:|
|  | Day before yesterday  |
|  | Yesterday |
|  | Today |
|  | Tomorrow |
|  | Day after tomorrow |

* When asking for the date, instead of  it becomes .

* "Last night" is . The  added to the end of  is a common addition to compound words.

####**This, Last, Next**

| Korean | English |
|:----------|-----------:|
|  | Last  |
|  | This |
|  | Next |
|  | Final |

These qualifiers come before the time period they describe

####**Years**

| Korean | English |
|:----------|-----------:|
|  | Last year  |
|  | This year |
|  | Next year |

####** vs **

*  is the Native Korean word for "year" and is used in some limited situations, like  (this year) and  (that year)

*  is the Sino-Korean word for "year" and other than the examples above, can also be used in  (this year), as well as the date with Sino-Korean numbers.

2017= 

####** vs **

*  is the Sino-Korean word for "day" and is usually used in the date, together with Sino-Korean numbers.

*  is the Native Korean word for "day" and is used most often in the names of holidays, with ordinal numbers ( =2nd day), and when describing a day ( =good day)

####** vs **

Month has a similar pair, with  being Korean and  coming from Chinese. When counting months, use Native Korean with  or Sino-Korean with .

####**Counting Days**

Just to make things fun, Korean has two ways of counting days. The first is just Sino-Korean number+, which is pretty easy.

The second way is based on the Native Korean numbers, but it's not so intuitive, so you'll have to memorize them.  is very commonly used, but the higher the number gets the more likely it is to be in Sino-Korean.

| English | Korean |
| - | - |
| One day |  |
| Two days |  |
| Three days |  |
| Four days |  |
| Five days |  |
| Six days |  |
| Seven days |  |
| Eight days |  |
| Nine days |  |
| Ten days |  |

####****

~ is a particle that means 'from.' It is used with dates and times instead of ~. 

####****

 means the time period of the preceding noun or phrase. It is usually followed by , but also the  is usually dropped. () can usually be translated to *during*. When used with a noun, simply put  after the noun and a space. With a phrase will be explained later.

Note: Nouns that cannot stand alone such as , , , , etc. are called **bound nouns**. A space is required before a bound noun, but there are two exceptions where the space is optional.

1. Time (**NOT** a duration)
2. Numerals

| Correct | Incorrect | Translation |
| - | - | - |
|  , , 100 , 100 |  | The year 100 |
|  , 100 , 100 |  | 100 years |

####**Roots**

| Korean | English | Character  |
| ------------- |-------------| -----|
|  | hour |  |
|  | minute |  |
|  | second |  |
